title: How has the proportion of people who drank heavily in the past week changed?
analysis_commentary:
The proportion of people who reported drinking heavily (over 8 units for men or over 6 units for women on their heaviest drinking day) in the past week decreased in the 16-64 age groups over the period from 2005 to 2014. In the 65 and over age group, the proportion of women who reported drinking heavily remained stable to 2013, but increased by 56% (to 3.3%) in 2014. The proportion of men aged over 65 who reported drinking heavily increased from 2011 to a peak of 8.3% in 2013 and fell again in 2014 to 7.5%.

The 16-24 age group saw the largest decrease in heavy drinkers of any age group over this time period, falling 9.5 percentage points. However, the decline in reported heavy drinking in this age group has slowed and 2014 saw an increase in the number of both men and women who reported drinking heavily. There was also a 12% increase (to 22.3%) in men aged 45-64 who reported drinking heavily.

The government published strategies to reduce alcohol related harm in 2007 and 2012. Public Health England has indicated that an independent evidence-based report on alcohol is a priority for 2016/17.
data_source: Office for National Statistics, Adult drinking habits in Great Britain: 2014
